awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The phenotypic consequences of adaptive introgression in naturally hybridizing primates
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent findings suggest that intermixing with now-extinct relatives like the Neanderthals may have helped humans adapt to new environments during their rapid expansion around the globe, and may still contribute to human differences in disease susceptibility today. However, the extent to which benefits to hybridization are also found in other primates is not well understood. This doctoral dissertation project will use a model for natural hybridization in primates to investigate signatures of beneficial transfer of genetic variants between species. It will also ask whether hybridization affects hair color and maturation timing in baboons, traits that may be important in mate competition, fertility, or survival. The research will provide novel insight into hybridization’s role in primate evolution and shed light on how hybridization may influence primate diversity in the future. It will also contribute to STEM education at the elementary, undergraduate, and graduate levels through the design of new educational activities, mentored research opportunities for undergraduate students, and support for the co-PI’s PhD training. Finally, this project will facilitate public engagement with science through free-to-the-public presentations that will also be accessible online.

To investigate the potential benefits of hybridization in primates, the project will integrate genomic and observational data from wild baboons. It will test the hypothesis that hybridization facilitates the transfer of a small number of advantageous genetic variants between yellow baboons and anubis baboons. To do so, genomic data will be generated for multiple populations spanning a baboon hybrid zone. These data will be subjected to three complementary methods to identify genetic variants affected by adaptive introgression. Cases of potential adaptive introgression will be investigated for overlap with genes that are also differentially expressed between yellow and anubis baboons. The project also will test the hypothesis that genetic ancestry predicts hair color and maturation timing in a well-studied baboon population at the center of the hybrid zone. It will assess whether ancestry effects on these traits differ in number and magnitude across the genome, based on evidence that hair and skin color traits tend to have a simpler genetic basis than life history traits like maturation timing. Finally, the project will test whether regions in the genome that contribute to ancestry-related differences in hair color or maturation timing are candidates for adaptive introgression.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Summary and Intellectual Merit

Hybridization, when two distinct taxa interbreed, was once thought to be rare but has now been documented in many animals. Ancient DNA analyses have extended this pattern to the ancestors of modern humans, who interbred with now-extinct archaic groups such as Neanderthals. Together, these findings suggest that hybridization may be the rule rather than the exception. However, we have limited insight into the consequences of hybridization and the factors that facilitate or limit it, especially in our own lineage.

To address this gap, this project focused on baboons--longstanding comparative models for human evolution--that naturally hybridize in Kenya. We sought to understand (i) hybridization's effect on traits related to reproduction and survival and (ii) natural selection's effects on introgression (i.e., transfer of genetic material via hybridization). By focusing on a wild population of hybrid baboons (individuals of mixed yellow baboon and anubis baboon ancestry) that have been studied under field conditions for many decades, we were able to show that hybrid ancestry affects mating patterns, but does not predict fetal loss for pregnant females, ruling out negative pregnancy outcomes as a strong barrier to hybridization. Nevertheless, we identified genetic evidence in support of costs to hybridization, which are particularly clear in regions of the genome that control levels of gene activity. Behavioral analysis suggests that assortative mating--when males and females with similar ancestry backgrounds are more likely to mate than those with different ancestry--may contribute to keeping these two baboon species distinct. Indeed, we identified pairs of genomic regions where ancestry predicts mating behavior in our population. These results emphasize the importance of behavior in shaping patterns of genetic variation in hybrid primate genomes.  

Together, this project provides some of the first analyses integrating field observations with population genomic data to understand the molecular and organismal-level consequences of hybridization in wild primates. Our results provide insight into what may have occurred in our own past, including the role of behavioral, fertility-related, and genomic barriers during human-archaic hominin admixture. Additionally, since climate change is expected to increase instances of hybridization as species change their geographic ranges, the results from this project provide insight into how hybridization is likely to shape primate trait diversity in the future.

 

Broader Impacts

This work supported four broader impact areas. First, the project supported the co-PI's efforts to increase opportunities for young scientists. For example, she presented her research and path in science to VASE (Virtual Active Science Engagement), a mentoring and peer-networking program for high school and undergraduate students interested in scientific careers. She also co-created and co-taught a 4-week lesson for an Introduction to Evolutionary Anthropology course. In this lesson, she introduced undergraduates to hands-on data exploration via developing their own research projects using the publicly available "Ecological traits of the world's primates" database (Galan-Acedo et al. 2019 Sci Data) and preparing, visualizing, and analyzing these data using RStudio. Additionally, the co-PI served as a mentor to eight first-year PhD students as they transitioned to graduate school, an undergraduate conducting an independent research study, and an undergraduate conference attendee. Second, the project contributed to encouraging public engagement with science in new and creative ways. The co-PI participated in The Art of A Scientist exhibit, an effort that fosters collaboration between scientists and artists to make science more accessible to the public. A scientific figure of her research was published alongside an artist's interpretation of it in an online zine. The co-PI also shared her research with the public through other creative media, including as part of a podcast (The Animal Behavior Podcast). Third, this project made a crucial contribution to the training of the co-PI by broadening her dissertation beyond its original scope and providing experience in new laboratory and computational skills. Fourth, this work sustained collaborations between American and Kenyan scientists, students, and field assistants, including co-authorships on two publications. It also supported continued investment in the local community where fieldwork occurs; the co-PI co-organized a fundraiser for purchasing food for >1,400 households in southern Kenya that faced extreme food shortages and economic challenges as a result of a severe drought.
